dialogues.text: Buildings lit against the night sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera follows group of partygoers as they mount the stai Truman Capote, Barbara (very tall), Rose, Christopher,  Williams.

dialogues.text: The friends are standing in the crowded kitchen -- people are coming in and out -- talking and drinking and laughin

dialogues.text: So Jimmy Baldwin tells me the plot  of his book, and he says to me: the  writing's going well, but I just  want to make sure it's not one of  those problem novels. I said: Jimmy,  your novel's about a Negro homosexual  who's in love with a Jew -- wouldn't  you call that a problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan's father had a minor heart  attack, so she's writing more erotic  poems about death and sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so tiresome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. What rhymes with angina?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter. We see Truman watching everyone laugh. GRAYSON  notices, leans in to him. As the rest of the group contin talking, we come closer, hear their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your writing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I've got a million ideas of what  to write next -- I just have to choose  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.text: Their attention is pulled back into the group as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who would I want to play me? Natalie  Wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too fat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey Hepburn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad. Sort of middle-class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When a movie is made of my life I  know exactly who I want as me... (beat) Marilyn Monroe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara cracks up, chokes on her drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman sits with his coffee, reading the New York Times. article catches his eye. He sits up straight, folds the p over, reads it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C/U of article being snipped out of PAGE 39 of the Times, November 16, 1959. As the page gets turned around with ea snip, we see a small PHOTO of a middle-aged man wearing  glasses, with the caption: "FOUND DEAD: Herbert W. Clutte a wealthy Kansas farmer..." We read the headline: "WEALTH FARMER, 3 OF FAMILY SLAIN. Parts of the story: "HOLCOMB,  Kan., Nov. 15 (UPI) -- ...wheat farmer, his wife... two y children found shot today..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Yorker magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Shawn, please. (he listens) Adorable one? All of a sudden I know  what article I'm going to write for  you next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman on the phone, on a long cord, travels between the  study and the kitchen as he talks to William Shawn. We he pieces of the conversation, and see Truman in different p of the room as he says each bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...never had anything like this happen  to them before. They're used to  sleeping at night with the doors  unlatched.... (laughs) Yes, we should buy stock in Master  Locks -- all of Kansas will be in  the hardware store tomorrow.

dialogues.text: Jump to -

dialogues.text: They have no idea who the killer is.  But it doesn't matter who the killer  is -- what matters is who the  townspeople imagine the killer is.  That's what I want to write about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jump to -

dialogues.text: I'm gonna need some help... I'm  thinking about Nelle -- she can  protect me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK DUNPHY (strong, Irish-American, ten years older than Truman) -- his longtime boyfriend -- enters the front doo with a bag of groceries, stops in the hall. He sees Truma on the phone. Truman looks at Jack, though he's still spe to Shawn --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to leave tonight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train barrels toward us, its headlight bright. The trai roars past, away from the city.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Truman hurries through the train, checking his ticket wit the sleeper cabins. His long SCARF trails behind. His lon cashmere COAT practically brushes the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman opens the door. Inside the cabin his childhood fri from Monroeville, Alabama, NELLE HARPER LEE (yes, that Ha Lee), is reading. She looks up, deadpan --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured you'd missed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle is a year younger than Truman, dowdy in dress, but  smart, tough, sensible. Truman smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God I'm glad you agreed to come.  You're the only one I know with the  qualifications to be both a research  assistant and personal bodyguard. (then, noticing) Oh, Nelle, you poor thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to spruce up her limp silk scarf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off. Truman. Off. (holds his hands) I'm happy to see you too, but I can  still whip your behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO BLACK PORTERS enter, one with an enormous TRUNK  (Truman's), the other with a sensible SUITCASE (Nelle's).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading tags) Mr. Truman Capote, Miss Nelle Harper  Lee. Where would you like these,  sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one up there and that one on  the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tips them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What all did you bring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you greatly, sir. It's an honor  to have you with us. If you don't  mind my saying, your last book was  even better than the first --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just when you think they've gotten  as good as they can get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. You're very kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nelle) Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PORTERS leave. Nelle is stunned. Truman fiddles with trunk locks, his back to Nelle. Silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You paid them to say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman won't look at her. She whacks him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You paid them to say that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squealing) How'd you know? How did you know?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Just when you think they've gotten  as good as they can get."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that was too much? (laughter) I thought that was a good line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More laughter. More smacking of Truman. Then it is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle's awake, but still in her bunk, looking out the win at the Kansas plains. Truman's dressing, watching her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRAVELING SHOTS of harvested FIELDS, grazing LIVESTOCK,  solitary FARMHOUSES. The TRAIN chugs across the Kansas flatlands. SHOTS of SIGNS outside Garden City: "World's Largest Free Swimpool" and "Howdy, Stranger! Welcome to Garden City. A Friendly Place. "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman and Nelle rent a car. People stare.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. RENTAL CAR
dialogues.text: Nelle drives past the main square, Truman in the passenge seat. Truman looks at a photo in THE GARDEN CITY TELEGRAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin Dewey, Kansas Bureau of  Investigation. KBI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman and Nelle check in. People stare. Nelle notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman and Nelle trot up the COURTHOUSE STEPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman approaches the GUARD DESK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Alvin Dewey, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third floor. In what used to be the  Sheriff's Office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman CURTSIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the reception area, ALVIN DEWEY and the two other KBI  AGENTS assigned to the Clutter case are getting their jac on and straightening their ties. They've completely taken over the office. They are: HAROLD "Brother" NYE (34); and ROY "Curly CHURCH (60 - bald). They all smoke. Sheriff WALTER SANDERSON -- 60's, kind, overweight -- is  office-less (though he and his wife DOROTHY still live on the fourth floor of the Courthouse.) WALTER lurks in the  background, nowhere to go, emptying one of many FILLED  ASHTRAYS, BOTHERED by the SMOKE. Truman and Nelle enter a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wife said no more smoking in the  house. I told her, "Fine. Walter's  got a couch upstairs in his apartment.  I'll stay with him and Dorothy till  we're done here." (to Walter) I've got my bag and a carton of  cigarettes in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER looks uncomfortable. Dewey shakes his head at Chur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dewey. Truman Capote from the  New Yorker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. The Agents stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Nye is looking at Truman, particularly puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bergdorf's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scarf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (then) Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (turns to Dewey) I wonder when we could arrange an  interview? Some time to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dewey stubs out his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not looking for any inside  information -- I don't care one way  or another if you catch whoever did  this -- I'm writing an article not  about the Clutter killings, but how  they're affecting the town, how you  all are bearing up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I care. (puts on his hat,  pulls out another  cigarette) I care a great deal if we catch  whoever did this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As do a lot of folks around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dewey walks out. Nye and Church start out after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Church) New Yorker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have press credentials?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the New Yorker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magazines don't give out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can come to the news conference  with the rest of them. (tips his hat to Nelle) Sears and Roebuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle and Truman are left alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed with PRESS from all over the Midwest, as well as l Finney County CITIZENS. Dewey's leading the press conference from a FOLDING TABLE set up in front of the Judge's bench, flanked by the two  other KBI Agents. He's got a cigarette burning in an asht Truman and Nelle stand in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk facts but I won't speculate.  The main fact here we need to be  clear on is not one, but four people  were killed. A lot of folks say Herb  Clutter had to be the main target  because he was dealt with the most  brutally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had his throat cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a moment) Yes. We'd all like to know why. But  it could've been any one of the family  they were after. We just don't know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've identified the murder weapon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wounds indicate a shotgun, close- range, but no casings were found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve-gauge, hunting --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were all shot in the face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dewey looks at the journalist. Then, evenly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Nancy in the back of the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any evidence of, I'm sorry,  sexual molestation of the women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else stolen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenyon's radio seems to be the only...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy was sixteen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen. Nancy was sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's her friend that found them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura Kinney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spell that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume you're okay with the Laura  part. K-I-N-N-E-Y. But, please, leave  her be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of folks try to talk at once, one OLD MAN makes hims heard above the rest:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's talk of a bunch of Mexicans,  a whole bunch of Mexicans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing, stubs out  cigarette) George, it's good to see you again.  I do have an opinion whether this  was the work of one man or a whole  bunch, as you said, but it doesn't  matter a whole lot whether it was  Mexicans or Methodists or Eskimos.  We're going to find whoever did this.  Four good people from our community  are dead. Let's remember that. Okay  with you? (holds up a notice) The West Kansas Farm Committee's  offering a thousand dollar reward  for information leading to an arrest.  Please print that. (moving to the exit) Thank you all for coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is immediately noisy as Dewey makes his way to t door, pulling a pack of cigarettes from his pocket, follo by Church and Nye. He's about to step out when Truman cat his eye. Dewey exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle drives while consulting a MAP. Truman is leaning ba looking out at the passing farms through the window. He s almost to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dewey's protective of the  Clutters. I wonder how well he knew  them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle glances over at him. He doesn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was foxy with that old man. (turns to Nelle) Are you ever gonna let me drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman, you're a menace. You can  barely see over the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman looks back out the window at the farms, leans back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This make you miss Alabama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rolling window down,  shakes his head) Not even a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans his head out, closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle pulls their car to the side of the COUNTY ROAD whic fronts the CLUTTER FARM. We recognize the FARMHOUSE as th one in which Nancy Clutter was found dead. A HIGHWAY PATR (20 years old) sits in a CRUISER parked up the driveway. CRIME SCENE TAPE marks the perimeter of the property. Tru and Nelle get out of their car, stand at the foot of the  driveway, gazing at the lonely farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gorgeous fall day. Crowds of kids arriving at school. M are SOMBER. As Truman and Nelle walk toward the kids, som look warily at Truman and give him a wide berth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids back away. Nelle notices. She leaves Truman, walks u to a group of THREE GIRLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can any of you tell me where I'd  find Laura Kinney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, um...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl glances toward the school entrance where LAURA K (who found Nancy Clutter's body) walks with DANNY BURKE ( 17).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Is that her? With the tall boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. With Danny Burke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny Burke? (Girl #2 nods) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nelle leaves, Girl #1 turns to her friend:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, quiet yourself, Janice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle sees Truman on his way toward Laura, calls out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman. Truman --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman doesn't hear. She watches Truman approach them. La backs away. Danny leads her off. Nelle walks over to Trum looks at him for several moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These folks live their lives in a  particular way. You need to consider  adapting yourself to that fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I'm gonna find out where those  two kids live. Maybe you'll let me  do that alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle leaves. On Truman, as the bell rings and the mass o teenagers starts to enter the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman walks alone, sees the Gilbart Funeral Home. He rem his hat, slips past the few people standing outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warm but slightly tacky. Some people are engaged in hushe conversation at the reception area. Truman slips past, in the back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No people, low light. Four CLOSED CASKETS at the back of room. Truman walks over slowly. After a moment, he checks make sure he's alone. Then he LIFTS THE TOP of one of the caskets. It's Bonnie Clutter's body, in a long-sleaved na blue dress; but her head is wrapped in layers and layers white cotton gauze, and lacquered with a shiny substance like an enormous cocoon. Truman stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman on the PHONE to Jack in Brooklyn. One of Truman's  trunks is open, displaying bottles of liquor, packaged an tinned gourmet food, and stacks of unused yellow legal pa He drinks, standing at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I scared a friend of yours  this morning. He came looking for  you while I was writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hate my friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't say hate. So long as they  don't knock on my door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw the bodies today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Clutters. I looked inside the  coffins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's horrifying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It comforts me -- something so  horrifying it's freeing. It's a  relief. Normal life falls away. (beat) But, then, I was never much for normal  life --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you weren't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People here won't talk to me. They  want someone like you, like Nelle.  Me they hate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't think of a single quality I  share with Nelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe manliness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My point exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's why I left the Midwest in the  first place. I knew I could only  find someone like you in New York  City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Truman, gazing at the EMPTY TOWN SQUARE below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHOPKEEPER sweeps the sidewalk. There are THANKSGIVING  DECORATIONS in his shop window. A SCHOOL BUS picks up a SMALL BOY at the intersection of DIRT ROAD and the paved COUNTY ROAD. A SMALL BRIDGE over the Arkansas river. Below them, men a sifting the riverbed with nets, moving slowly downstream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle waits by the FRONT DESK. The ELEVATOR DOORS open an Truman emerges. He is DRESSED SOBERLY -- NO LONG SCARF, N LONG COAT. He walks toward Nelle, then TURNS as if he's a runway model, walks away, turns again and walks back. He  stops a few feet in front of her. Nelle refuses to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny Burke walks down the road with a bookbag over his  shoulder. Nelle approaches him, Truman keeps his distance

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny? (Danny stops) Would you mind terribly if I walked  with you for a bit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs. They walk together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura opens door to Truman and Nelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle and Laura Kinney sit at the table. Truman stands at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were from the FBI with  your long coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I ran off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been getting a lot of that  lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman smiles. Laura smiles back, amused, a bit comforted

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine talking to you all.  Practically nobody around here wants  to talk since what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Folks have been through a rough patch.  Including you. (Laura nods) Nancy was your best friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was my best friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're quiet for a few moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How has Danny been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty shattered. Nothing terrible  ever happened to him before. Nancy  just started wearing his ring again  after this huge fight -- Mr. Clutter  was trying to get her to end it 'cause  Danny's Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were the Clutters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Methodist. Danny was the last person  at the house that night. That's why  Mr. Dewey's keeps interviewing him --  they don't think he had anything to  do with it -- just to see if he  remembers anything unusual and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People in town seem to wonder if he  was involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's been real hard for Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's the hardest -- when people  have a notion about you and it's  impossible to convince them otherwise.  Since I was a child folks have thought  they had me pegged because of the  way I look and the way I talk. They're  always wrong. (looks at her) Do you know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura stares at him and nods. He's clearly struck a chord

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes in the door to the GROUND FLOOR APARTMENT. They her through the LACE CURTAINS getting something from her  DESK, which is stacked with books. Truman whispers to Nel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not one person here understands her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura returns. She hugs a SMALL BOOK to her chest. After moment, she holds it out to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you'll get a better picture of  Nancy. And the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's her diary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle and Truman walk quickly back to the hotel. Nelle ha the diary open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Danny here tonight and we watched  TV. So nice just having him sit with  us. Left at eleven. P.S. -- He's the  only one I really love."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns the page. The rest of the book is blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that was that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The end of a life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle typing. Truman is propped up on pillows on the bed, scrunching his eyes to remember what was said that aftern then writing quickly on one of many YELLOW LEGAL PADS, ha the pages of interview dialogue to Nelle. He's exhausted. Nelle stops typing a moment, looks through the pages Trum has handed her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Shattered."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Pretty shattered. Nothing terrible  ever happened to him before. "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes some pillows aside and lies down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have 94 percent recall of all  conversations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've tested myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scans some of what  he's written) I hate that you're better than me at  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns back to the typewriter. She types. Truman lies  there, looking at the ceiling for a few moments. He close his eyes. Nelle knows without looking --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you dare close your eyes on my  bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. She keeps typing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand up and walk out that door. Go  to your room if you're gonna sleep.  Truman. Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle turns to look at him. He's asleep. She goes back to typing. Under her breath:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman drinks coffee alone, sleepy. He takes a SMALL BOTT of HOT-PEPPER TABASCO from his jacket pocket and shakes i over his EGGS. He replaces the bottle in his jacket. Nell walks into the lobby from upstairs, heads for Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What right do you have being tired?  You were snoring blissfully --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't snore --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- while I lay there, hating you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't hate me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much. (She sits. Truman  holds out a NOTE) What? (takes it, looks) Marie Dewey?... We've got somewhere  to go for Thanksgiving supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently Detective Foxy's wife has  a better opinion of me than Detective  Foxy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ding Dong. We see the FRONT DOOR open. Reveal MARIE DEWEY pretty, 35, dressed primly -- and her two boys: ALVIN JR. (9), and PAUL (6), lurking behind, curious. Marie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverse onto Nelle... and Truman, dressed in a DARK SUIT, hair neatly combed, like an Exeter schoolboy attending a  funeral. Nelle smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle nudges Truman, who hands over his gifts: a BOTTLE O J&B, and a PACKAGE of GOURMET SPICED NUTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soberly) Thank you for having us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock serious) Thank you. (then:) Get yourselves in here. (turns and walks into  the house) Alvin! Get your pants on. They're  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Nelle and Truman, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FOOTBALL GAME plays on the television. No one's watchin We can HEAR Alvin on the phone in his study at the back o the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman and Marie at the stove. Nelle sits at the kitchen  table. Truman has his jacket off and an apron on, as does Marie. They are peering into a POT OF BLACK-EYED PEAS. Ma is shaking in drops of HOT PEPPER TABASCO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More. More.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin will hate this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but we who know the truth will  love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) I have to stop. (then) I cannot believe you're from New  Orleans. I miss it so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only lived there for a short while  but my Mama was born and bred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know something -- Alvin pretends  he doesn't know who you are, but the  minute you came to town he read your  books. He had one of his men pick up  "Breakfast at Tiffany's" in Kansas  City 'cause it's banned from the  library here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did Mr. Dewey think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He liked it more than he's willing  to admit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How very foxy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marie smiles at that word used to describe her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama would've put in half the bottle  by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, one more shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin walks toward the kitchen. He smokes. He looks exhau He hears SQUEALS of laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin enters. They all stop laughing and look at him. nod to Truman and Nelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Marie sips her drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doing, foxy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cracks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remains of dinner. The kids have left. The bottle of sits on the table, half-empty. Marie's a bit drunk. Every PLATE is clean except for Alvin's, on which sits a MOUND uneaten black-eyed peas. Truman is mid-story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was writing the script as they  were filming, all that time in Italy.  I'd work like mad all day long and  then dash down to the bar around  midnight to hand in the next day's  scenes. Humphrey had just about moved  into the hotel bar --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers to Alvin) Humphrey Bogart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where he and John drank every  night --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Alvin) John Huston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and I mean drank, like famished  water buffaloes. Well -- I'd only  just handed them the final scene  when the bellhop told me I had a  phone call. It was my stepfather,  Joe Capote, calling to say that my  mother had died. I flew home to New  York -- terribly distraught -- but  when I got to the apartment I could  see that Joe was in even worse shape  than I was. He grabbed my hands and  sat me down at the kitchen table,  and he said to me, "Talk. Talk about  anything, any subject in the world.  Don't worry whether it will interest  me or not. Just talk so I won't break  down." And I did. He couldn't bear  to be alone with his thoughts. It  was too painful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quiet for a moment, then Marie looks at Alvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a hard couple weeks for  Alvin. He and Herb Clutter were good  friends. From church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on, Alvin. These are good  people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Dewey looks at Truman and Nelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin shows Truman and Nelle the CRIME SCENE PHOTOS from Clutter murders. We see the four corpses, BOUND and SHOT, the bloody footprints in the Clutter basement. Truman and Nelle stare at the photos of Nancy and Kenyon. Then, quie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who would put a pillow under the  boy's head just to shoot him? Why  would they tuck Nancy in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised by the  insight) I want to know the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman hands Nelle one of the photos. She looks at it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twisted notion of tenderness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman and Nelle are leaving. Alvin and Marie stand in th front door. Nelle kisses Marie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So many of my friends would love to  meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'd be fine --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dewey) You don't have to worry. I'm not  going to write about this until  everything's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not worried. I know what room  you're in at the hotel. And I know  where you live in Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC: "Have yourself a Merry Little Christmas..." Main  Street, CHRISTMAS LIGHTS in the TREES. The HARDWARE STORE, with Santa Claus DECORATIONS in the w and a "ONE WEEK LEFT TO BUY YOUR GIFTS..." sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman and Nelle walk with PETE HOLT (70, very frail) on Clutter property. Apples rot on the ground, the trees are bare, signs of disrepair are beginning to weather the hou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re the apples) I'd of picked them up but I haven't  been myself. Mind you, I make the  walk out here every day, check the  house, make sure the pipes don't  freeze -- that sort of item. The  least I can do for Mr. Clutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you worked here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1940 -- a lotta years. The wife too,  cleaning the house. Cooking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she's marvelous. Lunch was  wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring this) She had a hard job after what all  happened. Cleaning. I burned most of  the rest -- mattresses -- too far of  a mess. (then, looks at them) I've asked around some -- if anyone's  looking for a strong hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't know what to say. Finally, he looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think they'll be able to  sell the place till they catch the  ones that did it. (beat) That's what I hear anyhow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence as the three of them look out over the barren fie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the bed-frame -- the mattress is gone. Truman and Ne find her Bible on the bedside table, her bookmark, see th painting of Jesus walking on water. Pete Holt stands off the side, waiting patiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the front window we see a Christmas tree in the l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazzy Christmas music on the RADIO. Nelle sits in the big armchair with a drink. She laughs. We HEAR Jack on the ph

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're celebrating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Truman wearing a YELLOW SILK SHORT ROBE with white lace, bare legs. He's on the phone and walking, for Nelle enjoyment, back and forth, like a runway model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember Nelle's manuscript she sent  me in New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mockingbird. Killing a Mockingbird.  You said it was good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I was right. She just heard  Lipincott wants to publish it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Well. Jesus. That's terrific. Tell  her congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations. (covers phone, mouths  to Nelle:) Jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just promise you'll be home by  Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't leave now Jack -- I mean it  was hard at first, but now I'm  practically the mayor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He vamps. Nelle laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to come home -- I do. Though  if they catch whoever did this, who  knows what -- I'll probably be here  til next Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. I'll let you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, we'll go away this spring to  write. Maybe Spain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye. (hangs up) The poor boy misses me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goes to the mini-bar to fix a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember when we were kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was never a kid. I was born fully  formed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no idea what a homosexual was.  But I knew whatever they were, you  were one of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman puts down his drink and marches out of the room, s the door. Nelle's unsure whether she really insulted him. From the HALL, we hear a WOMAN SHRIEK, and a MAN saying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Uh. Oh. Excuse us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman runs back in, shuts door. They crack up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasteful Christmas lights strung on the BUSHES. A WREATH the FRONT DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman, Nelle, Marie and Alvin. Drinks. A FULL ASHTRAY on the coffee table in front of Alvin. He's distracted, smok Marie holds a WOMEN'S MAGAZINE, checking what Truman says with what's written there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly, as if  reciting) -- girdle up -- no extra bulges --  if you're dressed right for him when  he gets home, the evening should be  smooth sailing. Bon voyage, gals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you got this whole  page -- I only read it to you once! TRUMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've trained myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman looks at Nelle. TRUMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have 94 percent  recall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) You cut that out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin stubs out his cigarette -- though it still burns. H stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe that Alvin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. He's upset. (stubs out cigarette) -- smoking three packs a day. (then) Two men did it. They know who. One  of them used to have a cellmate who  gave him up for the thousand dollar  reward. They passed through Kansas  City last week writing bad checks --  by the time Alvin's boys got up there  they'd skipped out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas dinner. Truman, Nelle, Marie and Alvin have jus sat down. They wait for the Dewey boys -- Alvin Jr. and P We hear them in the living room horsing around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin. Paul. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quiet for a second. Then something crashes and break

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnit. (gets up, goes) Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin Jr. Get over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul. Back to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dewey returns to the dining room, pushing Paul ahead of h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin Jr. enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them we're at dinner, Alvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now, Alvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin Jr. leaves. We hear the PHONE being HUNG UP. Alvin returns and sits. They all get ready to say grace, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to call the Chief of Police  in Las Vegas when you have a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks at Dewey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVER BLACK SCREEN we hear the voice of a RADIO ANNOUNCER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This is KERG radio, Garden City.  A friendly broadcast from a friendly  place. Our lead story:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, the sounds of a CROWD emerge in the background. FADE UP ON: HIGH SCHOOL kids sitting on the hood and fron seat of a CHEW parked at the edge of a CROWD of 200 peopl Truman watches. It is COLD. A fat, shivering CO-ED reads headline in the Kansas City Star: "Police Fear Lynch Mob. The CAR RADIO is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...newsmen from six states have joined  scores of Kansans as they await the  arrival of confessed killers Perry  Smith and Richard Hickock. KBI  officers have been driving the Clutter  family's brutal killers nonstop  from...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman moves from the car into the large crowd. Old ladie ranchers; local businessmen; moms with kids; journalists  INTERVIEWING citizens; photographers lined up at the bott of the COURTHOUSE STEPS. We hear snippets of conversation we pass. A CITIZEN is being interviewed by a JOURNALIST; MOM WITH BABY standing with a FRIEND; a MIDDLE-AGED man i an overcoat CRYING silently. Truman approaches Nelle and Marie Dewey, standing togethe at the curb in front of the courthouse, near the  photographers. They are talking quietly, turn to Truman -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear LOUD CROWD NOISE at the south end of the square. CONVOY of FOUR CARS enters the square. It pulls around to the front of the courthouse. STATE TROOPERS spill out of lead and rear CARS. Nye gets out of the second car. He op the back door. The crowd falls SILENT. Two state troopers get DICK HICKOCK -- handcuffed, pale -- out of the car an lead him up the steps. FLASH. FLASH. Dewey and Church open the third car's back door. Silence. They retrieve PERRY SMITH. Perry is extremely SHORT, STRO ODDLY BEAUTIFUL, with the dark skin and hair of his Ameri Indian mother, and the pug features of his Irish father. he stands, he has trouble straightening his stubby LEGS, if they are arthritic. Truman stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers to Truman) Motorcycle accident. He broke them  and they never healed right. (Truman looks at her) Alvin told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman watches Perry, transfixed. Perry seems terrified o the crowd, all the faces, like a child. Perry scans the c His eyes fall on Truman. FLASH. FLASH. Truman and Perry l at each other as Perry is led slowly past. At the top of steps the COURTHOUSE DOORS slam shut.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: FADE IN: Truman knocks on the door, a NEWSPAPER, a BOOK, a PAPER BAG in his hand. On the door it says "SHERIFF'S  RESIDENCE - PRIVATE". Dorothy Sanderson opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman Capote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy Sanderson. I figured you'd  be left alone this morning by that  hard-working husband of yours. (holds up bag) So I have breakfast. (holds up paper) I have news. (book) And I have literature. My friend  Jack mailed me the book you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presents book. Dorothy, flattered, takes it, reads the inscription inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "For the maiden of the Midwest, the  priestess of the plains, the queen  of the kitchen: my first novel.  Truman."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is "Other Voices, Other Rooms" and we see on the back it the INFAMOUS JACKET PHOTO of Truman at 23 draped sexil on a couch. Truman curtsies. The PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too much. Go on into the living  room, lemme grab that -- it's been  ringing all morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman walks into the residence. To the left is the kitch to the right is the living room. Truman looks back at Dor she's still on the phone. He heads for the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman walks slowly through the doorway of the large kitc On the far side of the kitchen is a JAIL CELL. Inside the cell is PERRY SMITH. (Now we know why Truman came here.) Truman STARES. Perry doesn't see him -- he's resting his  head on a small table, the tip of his THUMB in his mouth. The chair seems too tall for Perry. He looks like a lonel kindergartner, told to take his afternoon nap. After seve moments, Dorothy enters, flustered:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Truman. I meant in there. (points to living  room) I... um...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry sits up quickly, rubs his legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the women's cell. It's hardly  ever used. But they wanted to, um,  separate... Please. Let's sit in the  living room. I'll set up in the living  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gathers a tray of Truman's PASTRIES, and COFFEE CUPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes -- Truman starts to follow, then lingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They put you in the women's cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among other indignities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry's voice is oddly high, whispery -- special words ar precisely enunciated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... she's a good cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's scared of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so am I. A little bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you? (a moment, then:) You have any aspirin? My legs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy's in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um. Truman? All set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman looks at Dorothy, looks back at Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge ROLAND TATE, white-haired, imperious, bangs his gav The packed crowd quiets down. Perry and Dick sit at the  defense table chewing JUICY FRUIT GUM. Next to them: thei aged court-appointed lawyer, Franklin Weeks (70). Dick wears a SHIRT AND TIE. Perry wears jeans rolled up a the cuff, his SHIRT OPEN at the collar. He draws on a pie of paper with a STUBBY PENCIL -- a rather good picture of LARGE PARROT. Truman sits with Nelle, watching Perry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmurs) His feet don't touch the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the matter of the State of Kansas  v. Richard Eugene Hickock and Perry  Edward Smith this Court has been  informed by counsel -- Mr. Weeks --  that defendants wish to waive their  right to Preliminary Hearing. Mr.  Hickock, is that your wish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hickock looks at Weeks. Weeks nods. Hickock stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unconvincing) Yessir. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hickock sits. Truman whispers to Nelle --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are they doing that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stands... then:) I ask that the waiver be effectuated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge Tate looks at him for a moment --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So noted. (bangs gavel) We're adjourned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowd gets up. Much talk. Truman watches Perry and Dick  through the forest of bodies. They are led away in handcu Franklin Weeks stands slowly, then begins gathering his t he's old and it takes him ages to collect his papers. Tru watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman knocks. He holds a PIE. Dorothy answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Capote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offers pie) Madame Sanderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that for the two of us to share?  Or for me to eat alone while you  talk to our guest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman is caught. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman sits near the bars of the cell. Perry draws on a s of paper at the small table. Dorothy watches from the doo to the living room. The BOOK Truman gave to Dorothy lies the floor next to Perry's meticulously made bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it your choice to waive the  hearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry doesn't answer. Dorothy checks her watch, leaves. T takes a bottle of BAYER ASPIRIN out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still need some? (Perry doesn't move) Give me your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry extends his hand through the bars. As Truman shakes some aspirin into it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could kill you if you got too close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry puts the aspirin in his mouth, CHEWS THEM, holds ou his hand for more. Truman gives him more, which Perry put in his pocket for later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like some water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry shakes his head. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Sanderson lent you my book --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said we'd curry favor with the  Judge if we waived our rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman nods, not wanting to push this any further. Perry  picks up the book, holds it out through the bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your picture's undignified. People  recall first impressions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's been your first impression?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy pokes her head in from the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman. Walter's gonna be home soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Perry) I just want permission to talk. (then) Has anyone else visited?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you tell me if you need anything?  I can have whatever you want sent  from New York. (no answer) Will you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Perry, considering whether to trust this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone RINGS, WILLIAM SHAWN answers (50, New Yorker editor conservatively attired) at a desk looking onto 44th stree

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Shawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gorgeous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT to Truman in a PHONE BOOTH outside the COURTHOUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm writing a book. It's too much  for a single article -- this town,  the killers most of all -- you will  be stunned by Perry Smith --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? What has he --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much yet, but I know. I can sense  him. He's desperately lonely,  frightened... I have questions --  are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it matter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much more money can you send me?  How quickly can you get Dick Avedon  out here to take some pictures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT to WILLIAM SHAWN'S OFFICE. On Shawn -- he doesn' know how to begin to respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry has been placed in an adjoining cell for the aftern He COMBS his greased hair in a mirror. A camera FLASHES. Nelle and Truman sit outside the cells. Franklin Weeks do off to the side. RICHARD AVEDON -- small, dark, wiry,  flamboyant -- is snapping photos of a bare-chested Hickoc in the next cell, particularly his TATTOOS, while Hickock chatters away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry, honey. You look terrific...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry is embarrassed, glances over at Truman. FLASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm yourself down, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry glances at Nelle. She MOTIONS to him that his SHIRT buttoned wrong. Perry fixes it, looks back at her. Hickock notices Truman gazing at his tattoos -- the one o his CHEST: the word PEACE, with a cross radiating rays of light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be patient, Capote. Maybe later  they'll send you my skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have the perfect place for it,  over the hearth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hickock smiles. FLASH. Truman looks over at Perry, sittin alone. Truman starts to remove his TIE. PHOTOS, in quick succession: Of Hickock pulling up his sl to reveal his tattoos. Of Perry combing his HAIR. FLASH. GRINNING CAT on Hickock's hand. FLASH. Perry looking dire at the camera. FLASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Series of shots in and around the courthouse: TITLE UP:             "One month later" An officer approaches down a long hallway. A janitor clea the basin of the water fountain. Spectators are drawn int the courthouse. The officer opens the courtroom doors. A  crescendo of sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spectators take seats. The jury files back into the box.  Perry and Dick chew gum. Perry wears TRUMAN'S TIE, and dr on a pad with a NEW SET OF COLORED PENCILS -- another PAR quite beautiful, now YELLOW. Nelle and Truman sit togethe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd Perry get the art set?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman shrugs. Nelle raises her eyebrows. Judge Tate GAVE loudly, looks to the jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Members of the jury. Have you reached  a verdict?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stands) Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Defendants rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry and Dick stand. Judge Tate turns back to the Forema

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry Edward Smith and Richard Eugene  Hickock stand accused of four counts  of the crime of murder in the first  degree. Have you reached a unanimous  verdict?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your verdict?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guilty. On all counts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you unanimously reached a  sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the sentence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge nods, the foreman sits. Judge turns to Perry and Di

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry Edward Smith and Richard Eugene  Hickock. You've been found guilty of  four counts of murder in the first  degree. You will be taken to the  state penitentiary at Lansing. No  later than midnight, May 13 of this  year, nineteen hundred and sixty,  each of you will be hanged by the  neck until dead. So ordered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He GAVELS. Perry and Dick are set upon by Sheriff's Deput and led out. Photographers crowd them. Dick turns to Perr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, partner. Least now we're  not the only killers in Kansas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry looks at him, utterly lost. FLASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle sits at the window, smoking. Truman in the armchair holding a drink. They've been up all night. Their bags ar packed. Also -- a few packed boxes of written -- in yello notepads and many typed pages. Truman glances at his watc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think he slept at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle looks over at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to see him before we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman sits next to Perry's cell. Perry lies on the bed,  staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to transfer you up to  Lansing today. You'll have to make  sure to put me on the visitor's list.  Otherwise I can't see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you do that? I'm going to help  find you a proper lawyer. You need a  serious lawyer for an appeal. (no response) They took Dick last night. I need  you to get him to do the same thing --  put me on the visitor's list. Will  you do that, Perry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE UP ON the sounds of a HUGE PARTY in progress. We see home-made BANNER reading "Return to Civilization!" The CA follows NELLE as she walks through the crowd: Gays, strai smoke and noise. Society women, slender and beautiful; BE BARON pontificating to CHRISTOPHER ISHERWOOD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle. Kudos on "Kill the Bird." Is  that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close enough. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Shawn talks to a MUCH TALLER WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't written a word yet, though  he says it's the nonfiction book of  the decade...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR Truman before we see him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's little, but terrifying --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Truman in the corner entertaining a small group. J Dunphy stands off to the side. Nelle settles next to Jack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's as short as I am. And almost as  pretty. I'd be with him right now  but he's being given new  accommodations --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guests laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most people assume he's a monster. I  don't see him that way. The book I'm  writing will return him to the realm  of humanity -- it's the book I was  always meant to write...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle and Jack stand back, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch out. This is the start of a  great love affair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Truman in love with Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman is being interviewed over lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I was in Marilyn's apartment just  last week. I had to break it to her  that, of the four Matisses hanging  on her wall, two were upside down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The REPORTER laughs. A waiter passes. Truman taps his gla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another. (to reporter) To answer your question, I'm following  "Breakfast at Tiffany's" by blazing  a different path -- by inventing an  entirely new kind of writing: the  non-fiction novel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a subject?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman takes a last sip of his drink -- utterly serious n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the night of November 14, two men  broke into a quite farmhouse in Kansas  and murdered an entire family. Why  did they do that? It's been suggested  that this subject is tawdry -- it's  not worthy of literature. I disagree.  Two worlds exist in this country --  the quiet conservative life, and the  life of those two men -- the  underbelly, the criminally violent.  Those worlds converged that bloody  night. I spent the past three months  interviewing everyone in Kansas  touched by that violence. I spent  hours talking to the killers -- and  I'll spend more. (waiter brings his  drink) Researching this work has changed my  life, altered my point of view about  almost everything. I think those who  read it will be similarly affected. (he sips) Such a book can only be written by a  journalist who has mastered the  techniques of fiction --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're speaking of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're really very clever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman sits in bed, writing on a yellow LEGAL PAD, surrou by PILES of notes. He squints his eyes, concentrating. Ja enters, delivers a CUP OF COFFEE. Truman doesn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman is rifling through the boxes, looking for particul notes. He can't find what he needs. The phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Truman walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry's decided to appeal. He claims  their attorney was incompetent --  that he never raised the issue of  temporary insanity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you find them a new lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're facing execution in six weeks,  Jack. They need someone to argue  whether or not that's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd also like to see them alive,  yes, thank you very much. I need to  hear their story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in silence for a few moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you met him you'd understand.  It's as if no-one's ever asked him a  single question about himself. He's  so... damaged -- and strange --  unexplored... (then) I don't trust this Hickock fellow.  Perry's the only person who can  describe to me what happened that  night. I need to hear him say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just be careful what you do to get  what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm finding them a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman. You're finding yourself a  lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman drives alone, concentrating intently. He has to st to see over the dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A turreted, Civil War-era fortress an hour's drive from K City. Truman pulls up to the GUARDHOUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman waits alone, looking at the lone decoration: a cam poster, showing a fat man in a suit grinning while holdin shotgun. Across the bottom it reads: WALK TALL WITH KRUTC A YOUNG PRISON GUARD sticks his head out of the office do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warden Krutch will see you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wood-paneled walls, government-issue desk. On the wall be the desk is a CHART -- a racial accounting of the current inmate population. It reads: WHITE - 1405, COLORED - 360, MEXICANS - 12, INDIANS - 6. WARDEN MARSHALL KRUTCH is fat, coarse, sweaty even in win And it's spring. He's running for Congress -- there are  "KRUTCH FOR CONGRESS" bumper stickers laying around the  office. He's enjoying a chance at a little publicity. The YOUNG PRISON GUARD stands quietly by the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do well by our boys. Showers once  a week. Feed em good. We'll be feeding  Perry Smith in the infirmary soon if  he don't eat. Get the food in through  his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasn't eaten in a month. But it's  not his right to kill himself. It's  the People's right. The People of  this State. And that's who I work  for, the People. You can write any  of this down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah. Won't eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When can I see him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking desk calendar) How about you come back Thursday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's no good. I need to see  them now, then whenever I want for  as long as I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not how we do things here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman glances at the campaign stickers, the young prison guard, then back at Krutch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand what a burden unlimited  visitation might be -- on this  institution, and on the People who  pay for it. I want to be clear that  I don't expect the citizens of  Leavenworth County to have to shoulder  that burden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman reaches into his jacket, pulls from it an ENVELOPE STUFFED with CASH. He lays it on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be dispensed as you see fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krutch is stone-faced as he regards the money. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know where to count your  boy -- being half-Indian. I did him  a favor though. (points to race chart) Counted him White.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a kind and generous man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second floor of a small building in the corner of the prison complex. Decrepit. The one hall is lit by mesh-cov BARE BULBS in the ceiling. Twelve cells -- six on each si Each is 7 by 10 feet, with one small, high WINDOW covered bars and wire. The YOUNG PRISON GUARD opens the heavy GAT at the end of the hall and shows Truman in. They walk down the row of cells. In one of them we notice Lowell Lee Andrews (20, white, spectacled, ENORMOUSLY FAT peering at his own face 4 inches from a mirror. Dick is leaning against the bars of his own cell. He smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for your help with the lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be desperate for a story to  come all the way out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Capote. You're entitled to go  in. You may, um, go in. If you wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman hesitates for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to see Perry. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman walks to the next cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask me, he's just trying to prove  the insanity defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman sees Perry, gaunt, lying on his cot, almost comato Perry's rather striking drawing of a LARGE YELLOW PARROT  sits propped on his table. An UNEATEN LUNCH TRAY lies on floor -- a cockroach runs over it. Truman watches, distur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera follows Truman as he walks down an aisle with a sm WICKER BASKET. He stops, looks at a shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman waits in the check-out line behind a MOM paying fo her groceries. Her SON (3) stands next to her legs, weari a little cowboy hat and cradling a TOY GUN to his chest. sucks his thumb. Truman and the boy look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman sits on the chair, his WICKER BASKET on the table. has spread out a cloth napkin. A GUARD watches from outsi the cell. Perry lies completely still on the cot. Truman  takes out jars of BONNET BABY FOOD, inspects the labels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Perry) I don't care what your plans are for  yourself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He decides on the CUSTARD jar. He opens it, takes a plast BABY SPOON from the basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're gonna wake up enough to  tell me what you did with my tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spoons a bit into Perry's mouth. The GUARD walks away. Truman leans close to Perry, whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. It's Truman. It's your  friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry sleeps. Truman stands against the wall watching him He has cleaned up the basket of food. He walks over to Pe desk, sees two handwritten notebooks on it: THE PRIVATE D OF PERRY EDWARD SMITH and PERSONAL DICTIONARY. Next to th he sees a pencil SELF-PORTRAIT Perry drew. It's very good Truman touches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry sleeps. Truman sits on the chair watching, waiting. Perry opens his eyes, looks at Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry is sitting up a bit, Truman helps him sip a cup of  water. Perry lies back down. He's looking at Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you learn to draw like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman drives through the KANSAS STATE PENITENTIARY gate, waves to the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry sits on the bed, cleaned up, wet hair neatly combed looking at a few OLD SNAPSHOTS he has saved in a handkerc Truman sits in the chair across from him. Perry hands him photo of his mother. Perry speaks quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before she had us. Before she started  drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who took care of you as a child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orphanage. Me and Linda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry nods. Truman waits for more. It doesn't come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not so different as you might  think. I was abandoned repeatedly as  a child. My mama'd drag me along to  some new town so she could take up  with another man she'd met. Night  after night she'd lock me in the  hotel room -- Mama'd turn the latch  and tell the staff not to let me out  no matter what. I was terrified --  I'd scream my head off -- till finally  I'd collapse on the carpet next to  the door and fall asleep. After years  of this she just left me with  relatives in Alabama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who raised you up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Aunts. (Perry nods) That's when I met Nelle -- she lived  next door. (looks again at the  photo, hands it back) Your mother was Indian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cherokee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drinking was not a good thing for  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No tolerance for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No tolerance for him either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman's laughs, surprised by the joke, though it's uncle whether Perry meant it as one. He stares at Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I can't decide is if you  understand how fascinating you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry doesn't respond, then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about your tie. They took  it away from me because we're all on  suicide watch. It's why the lights  stay on at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope we're past that now. You had  me worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about the tie. It's  just a pity because it looked so  good on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry leans in, motions toward Dick's cell, lowers his vo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful of Ricardo. I think he  wants you all to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's naturally mendacious -- not  to be trusted -- if he had a hundred  dollars he'd steal a stick of chewing  gum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry shakes his head. Then, Truman nods toward Perry's  notebooks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to take your notebooks with  me -- I want to read them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I leave here without understanding  you, the world will always see you  as a monster. I don't want that -- I  don't see you that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment, then Perry reaches for the NOTEBOOKS, hands the to Truman. Then he hands Truman the DRAWING he did of him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tracked my father down in Alaska.  I was 14. One day I said to him,  "Mom's dead." I could see it. A week  later we got the news. She finally  drunk herself to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman regards Perry. Then he looks at the drawing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is remarkable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes you see a thing -- how it  really is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Truman holding the drawing, looking at Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman walks quickly to his car, holding Perry's DRAWING NOTEBOOKS. At the car, he looks back at the dark jailhous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman at the desk, PERRY'S TWO BOOKS next to a LEGAL PAD already filled with notes. He's on the PHONE with Nelle,  paging through the PERSONAL DICTIONARY captivated by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He trusts me -- that's why he gave  it to me. He's given me absolutely  everything. (paging through Diary) You should see his drawings, Nelle,  how good he is. He wants so badly to  be taken seriously, to be held in  some esteem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT with Nelle, in pajamas, sitting on the porch of home in Monroeville, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold him in esteem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... he's a gold mine. I mean  he's told me his entire life, and  now it's all here for me to write  down -- All of the history I need.  His entire life in this Diary. His  dead mother. A brother and sister  killed themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell him your mama did the same  thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell him everything. We've been  talking our heads off the past month.  Sometimes, when I think how good my  book can be, I can hardly breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finds what he wants) Here's what I wanted to read to you:  "If Called Upon to Make a Speech:" --  this is exactly what I was talking  about -- a speech just in case he's  ever recognized for an achievement:  "If Called Upon to Make a Speech: I  can't remember what I was going to  say for the life of me. I don't think  ever before have so many people been  so directly responsible for my being  so very, very glad. It's a wonderful  moment and a rare one. Thank you!" (beat) There's an exclamation point on the  end of that thank you, in case you  didn't catch it... (silence) Where'd you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear Nelle exhale her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ. I guess it stopped being  funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said it was. (turns a page) Listen to this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman is eating breakfast with Alvin Dewey. A WAITRESS  refills their coffees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to waitress) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves. An uncomfortable silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're nothing if not hard-working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
