dialogues.text: You look good, healthy again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dewey taps a cigarette out of his pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've decided on a title for my book.  I think you'll like it -- very  masculine. "In Cold Blood."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lights the cigarette) That refers to the crime or the fact  that you're still talking to the  criminals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The former, among other things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They eat for a moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been wanting to ask if you'll  let me look at your investigation  notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That lawyer you helped find for your  friends got them a hearing at the  Kansas Supreme Court --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- on the issue of inadequate counsel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin. Do you not want me to look at  your notes? You are permitted to say  no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rises, takes out  wallet) I'll tell you what: if those boys  get off, I'm coming to Brooklyn to  hunt you down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman can't decide whether Dewey is kidding or not. Dewe puts money on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to be in court at nine o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks away. Over his shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call Roy Church. He'll show you what  you want to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman walks down the hall. He passes Dick's cell. Dick i lying in bed. Dick rises and smiles widely at Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman smiles, puts HIS FINGERS TO HIS LIPS, continues pa He stops outside Perry's cell. Perry (looking MUCH HEALTH is drawing at his table -- a picture of the HUGE YELLOW P swooping down from the sky. Truman watches for a few mome then Perry looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard locks Truman inside with Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman looks at the Guard -- he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was as much for me as for anyone.  I couldn't bear the thought of losing  you so soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to be able to use your  book for our case. You'll write we  never got to raise our insanity plea.  You wrote how terrible the lawyer  was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't written a word yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you been doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Research. Waiting to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had hoped --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you calling it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The book? (looks directly at  him) I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm going to write about you --  if I'm going to determine how to  write about you -- you need to tell  me about that night at the Clutter  house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Do you worry what I'll think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry looks away. A long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick says you know Elizabeth Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a lot of people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman gives up for now. Sees the PICTURE OF THE YELLOW B on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that you keep drawing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must hate having to come to this  place --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry, I have invitations to be in  Morocco, Greece... I choose to be  here. Those people have everything,  all their prayers have been answered,  yet they're more desperate than ever.  I prefer to be here with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at Truman;  evenly) I was ten, I wet the bed, the nuns  at the orphanage hated the smell.  First month one of them found me  shivering -- just trying to get  through the night. The Sister pulled  back the covers and shined her  flashlight to see what I'd did. The  sheets were wet. She hit me so many  times with that flashlight she broke  it. (he shrugs) That night I dreamed about the yellow  bird. Tall. Yellow like the sun. It  picked me up and it clawed the Nun's  eyes and it lifted me into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman on the street outside the club at a PAY PHONE. He  talks with Jack in Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just missing this one piece,  Jack. Be patient with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is that gonna take? Why  don't you try leaving him alone for  a while? Come to Spain. You can always  visit him later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm off. I've got my own writing  to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it in Brooklyn. Wait for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too many people around. (beat) I'll leave the address on the kitchen  table. Truman, what do you do there  when you're not with him? -- It must  be awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman's watching a YOUNG GUY standing outside the bar,  looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about what I said. Join me  when you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. I will. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman follows the YOUNG GUY into the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman sleeps. He OPENS HIS EYES in bed. Turns to the bed table to see the drawing of Perry looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young drifter stands alone on an empty street corner. H checks a pay phone for a coin. It's empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry is lying on his cot reading an ADVENTURE MAGAZINE - something to do with finding buried treasure off the coas of Mexico -- and sucking on the tip of his thumb. After a moment he STARTLES and looks up. Truman stands outside his cell. He holds a stack of books Perry's PERSONAL DICTIONARY and DIARY, and a new WEBSTER' DICTIONARY and THESAURUS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see you. Jesus, you... (stands, tucks in  shirt) Come in. Where's the guard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I brought you some things,  but I have to fly back East.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you going there to see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from next cell) Capote, get it straight in your book --  we never intended on killing that  family --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No premeditation --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry searches the cell for something else to give to Tru to keep him there. Then, he stops. He has nothing left to give, and is unwilling to talk about that night at the  Clutters. He becomes very still. Truman speaks gently --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your writings are magnificent. I  hope these help you do more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response. Truman places the books on the floor just ou Perry's cell -- Perry's writings in one stack and the new dictionaries in another right next to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have so much material -- from the  trial, from our visits, your journals.  I have to organize it all, and I  have to start the process of writing. (no response) I'll visit soon. Perhaps this fall. (backing away) I miss you already. Write me every  five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and goes. We stay with Perry as Truman leaves. W hear Dick speak to Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be good now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear Truman's footsteps receding. Then, a long shot of th hallway as the Guard lets Truman out the gate at the end the row. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry looks down at the books sitting on the floor outsid his cell. He crouches, puts his hand through the bars and touches the cover of the new dictionary. He's alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over black -- the sound of a JET airplane -- loud, then  passing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE IN: BRIGHT WHITE SKY. Sounds of seagulls. Ocean, san cottage houses in greenery set back from the beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house Jack rented. Jack types on the upstairs deck. T pulls up in an OLD TAXI. Jack looks out over the railing the street. Jack emerges on the FRONT PORCH as Truman wal up the path with his bags. They look at each other. Then  Truman looks around at the incredible garden, the ocean i the background, and starts to LAUGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Title up:              "January, 1962" Sound of a MANUAL TYPEWRITER over black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE IN on the peaceful outside of the house. Sound of TY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More typing. A PHONE rings. CAMERA tracks slowly through pretty, tiled living room, toward a DOOR at the far end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman at his DESK, surrounded by piles of filled YELLOW  PADS, NOTE CARDS, an open TRUNK of random notes. He is at the MANUAL TYPEWRITER. The phone is on the floor, ringing He types. The phone rings. Exasperated, he picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman. I was supposed to be home  for dinner with my wife three hours  ago -- I have not been able to tear  myself away from your book. It's  that good. It's not good, it's  astonishing. This first half is  astonishing. If the second half lives  up to this it, -- it -- how much is  left to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT with Shawn's OFFICE at the New Yorker, NIGHT. Sh has a stack of manuscript pages on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm already well into the third part,  but I -- I can't finish that till I  convince Perry to describe the night  of the killings to me. I was planning  to visit this fall, see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you need to talk to him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we all need to see how this ends  for the final part. I can't finish  the book till I know what happens.  If Perry and Dick are executed it's  one thing -- and if not, well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman. You got your ending --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kansas court denied their appeal.  It came over the wire on Friday. You  need to talk to Perry now. He'll be  dead by September. I'm sorry, I know  how much you've come to care about  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman is completely immobile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Yes. Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to set up a reading for you  in the fall, in New York. We'll build  some interest, and we'll publish in  the fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman at the stove watching his tea water heat up. Jack  enters with a HUGE BASKET of WINE and GROCERIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plums. Thank god. We have nothing in  the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes one from the basket. Jack starts to unpack food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why aren't you working?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you couldn't be depended on  to stock the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman looks at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would we feed our famous guest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus. I completely forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He helps Jack put away the groceries. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (utterly nonchalant) Plus -- I finished my novel yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman looks at Jack, smiles widely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman, Jack and Nelle. A BONFIRE, a wind-up Victrola pla Ella Fitzgerald, bottles of wine. Jack and Nelle dance. T toasts Jack drunkenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My man, my hero, my talented... My  man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are the hardest worker, the most  unsung talent I know. As Nelle passes  by on her way to London to sell her  book which needs no selling, may a  little of her success rub off on  both of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle tries to smack Truman but can't catch him. The song changes to a slow one. Jack and Truman dance sweetly toge Nelle sits on the sand and watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast. Truman and Nelle are sitting -- Nelle has a sm envelope in her hand. Truman is obviously uncomfortable. Jack delivers a platter of omelettes to the table:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Truman) When was the last time you wrote  back to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter for your boyfriend I was  asked to deliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits. Nelle opens the letter, reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear Friend Truman. Where are you?  Read this item in a medical  dictionary: "Death by hanging is  caused by asphyxia, by fracture of  the cervical vertebrae, by laceration  of the trachea." Not too comforting  as we lost our appeal. Missing you --  alone and desirous of your presence.  Your amigo, Perry."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Shawn told me about the court  decision yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering why you were in such  a good mood. Surely, I thought, it's  not because I finished my little  book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a terrible thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks out at the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to no one in  particular) I used to write him all the time.  I've been so focused lately on the  book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman and Nelle carry her bags down the front walk towar waiting TAXI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack says I'm using Perry, but he  also thinks I fell in love with him  when I was in Kansas. How both of  those things can be true is beyond  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you? Fall in love with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence as they load the bags into the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman? --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to answer that...  It's as if Perry and I started life  in the same house. One day he stood  up and walked out the back door while  I walked out the front. With some  different choices, he's the man I  might have become.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman shrugs, doesn't answer. Nelle kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be nice to Jack. Sometimes I think  he's what I like about you best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) I'll see you at the reading in New  York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sixteenth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle gets in the taxi, then leans her head out the windo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman. Honestly. Are you going back  to Kansas because you care about  Perry or because you need information  before he's killed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't it be both?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't think it can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drives away. Truman watches her go. He turns back up  toward the house, stops a moment to pick a FLOWER from th bushes at the front gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Guard walks down the corridor carrying a SINGLE FLOWER. delivers it to Perry, then walks off. Perry is confused. hears FOOTSTEPS approaching, but can't see who it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, buddy. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More footsteps. CAMERA on Perry as the footsteps finally  arrive outside his cell. He's shocked. REVERSE onto Truman, looking tanned, healthy, very blond. holds a STACK OF BOOKS with a BOW on top. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT of dimly lit corridor, light spilling out from  each cell. A ROW GUARD walks the hall. We hear voices  murmuring. SIX MORE GUARDS arrive at the top of the stairs. The ROW  GUARD walks over, unlocks the GATE to let them in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry is looking at the cover of a BOOK -- "WALDEN POND." Other books sit next to Perry on the cot. Among them -- W CATHER's "MY ANTONIA", also "GREAT EXPECTATIONS" --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was he in jail for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said it was not paying his taxes.  But really for being an outsider --  refusing to go along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry nods, looks at the other books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to read any of these  if you don't want to. But I thought  you'd like something decent. You're  much too smart for adventure  magazines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the bars of Perry's cell, we can see the SIX GUAR enter Lowell Lee Andrew's cell (diagonally across the  corridor). The ROW GUARD appears at Perry's cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock-down while Lowell goes to  solitary. Nobody in or out. (to Truman) You want in or out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman looks at Perry, then back to the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The SIX GUARDS start to pack up Andrews cell while he sit on the cot and watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry and Truman talk very QUIETLY. (Throughout this scen we see in the background, across the corridor, the mostly obscured cell of Andrews. We see his incredibly FAT LEG b shackled, his belongings being packed in boxes.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone says he's a genius. I don't  think he's a genius. He's rich and  he went to college -- like any of us  would've if we got the chance. He  came home for Christmas and shot his  parents --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- in front of the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember the story --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were watching Father Knows Best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other and smile. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be sorry to see him go. Always  correcting my grammar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch Andrews being shackled in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now -- Dick and me -- we're next in  line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman regards Perry, who looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry I've been away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you could come next week,  when they take him out to the Corner,  but the whole prison shuts down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to be in New York anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the book going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you show it to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've hardly written anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the six guards CLANGS Andrews' cell bars with his  stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ROW GUARD opens the cell door. Andrews is led out, ar and legs shackled, into the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your head high, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...or they won't be able to rope you  under your fat fucking chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrews is led past Perry's cell. He looks in at Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrews shuffles down the hall. Perry watches him go. On  Truman watching Perry. We hear the GATE slam shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed. Nelle stands with William Shawn, who receives wel wishers. BEN BARON enters, seeing Nelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly, over the  hubbub) Hello Hollywood. That's quite a bundle  you sold your book for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle is embarrassed, mostly for Baron, to have the issue money brought up publicly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron moves past, Nelle smiles politely, whispers to Shaw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman sits alone. In the background, we can HEAR the noi of the huge crowd gathering in the theater. Truman wears MOST STYLISH LITERARY OUTFIT: a gorgeous dark green Knize SUIT over a black cashmere turtleneck sweater, and horn-r GLASSES (which we've never seen him wear before). He's frozen with anticipation, nervousness. After several moments a THEATER ASSISTANT opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Capote. Can I get you anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (clears his throat) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assistant leaves. We hear the crowd quiet down. Truma rises slowly, walks through the door to the backstage are We hear William Shawn on stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome New Yorkers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shawn pauses briefly for a laugh that doesn't come. Truma continues walking toward the backstage curtains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming to the first  public reading, the first offering  of any kind, of Truman Capote's new  work "In Cold Blood." Our magazine --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman walks on stage. Loud applause. Shawn sees him, sli back to his seat. Truman walks over to the podium, takes the enormous crowd. Once it is completely quiet:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. My name is Truman Capote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People laugh and applaud loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry, eating dinner alone at his table, looks up. We HEA LOUD ENGINE revving outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FRONT-LOADER TRACTOR drives into the warehouse. A PRISO POLICE CAR parks outside the warehouse. Guards get the  enormous Lowell Lee Andrews, shackled, from the back seat walk him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C/U on Perry, now standing on his chair and watching out tiny window.

dialogues.speaker: INT THEATER, NYC
dialogues.text: Truman on stage reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry Smith's voice was both gentle  and prim -- a voice that, though  soft, manufactured each sound exactly --  ejected it like a smoke ring issuing  from a parson's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry watches through his window. From inside the warehou we hear the gallows TRAP DOOR spring and CLATTER. On Perr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman reading. Utter silence except for his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The village of Holcomb stands on the  high wheat plains of western Kansas,  a lonesome area that other Kansans  call "out there." Until one morning  in mid-November 1959, few Americans --  in fact, few Kansans -- had ever  heard of Holcomb. Like the waters of  the [Arkansas] river, like the  motorists on the highway...  exceptional happenings had never  stopped there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the outside wall with Perry and Dick's faces peeri out through their tiny windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TRACTOR emerges through the warehouse doors. It carri in its FRONT SHOVEL the enormous, dead BODY of ANDREWS co by a BLACK CLOTH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman reading. The audience completely still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four coffins, which quite filled  the small, flower-crowded parlor,  were to be sealed at the funeral  services -- very understandably, for  the effect... was disquieting. Nancy  wore her dress of cherry-red velvet,  her brother a bright plaid shirt;  the parents were more sedately  attired, Mr. Clutter in navy-blue  flannel, his wife in navy-blue crepe;  and -- and it was this especially  that lent the scene an awful aura --  the head of each was completely  encased in cotton, a swollen cocoon  twice the size of an ordinary blown- up balloon, and the cotton, because  it had been sprayed with a glossy  substance, twinkled like Christmas- tree snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TRACTOR rolls the body into the BED of a waiting PICK TRUCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry watches through his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman reading. The audience transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagination, of course, can open any  door -- turn the key and let terror  walk right in. [One] Tuesday, at  dawn, a carload of... strangers,  ignorant of the local disaster --  were startled by what they saw as  they crossed the prairies and passed  through Holcomb: windows ablaze,  almost every window in almost every  house, and, in the brightly lit rooms,  fully clothed people, even entire  families, who had sat the whole night  wide awake, watchful, listening. Of  what were they frightened? "It might  happen again."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes his manuscript. Several moments of SILENCE, the thunderous APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman's dressing room. Packed with well-wishers drinking from bottles of CHAMPAGNE, smoking, toasting, shouting to heard. Truman in the corner with Christopher Isherwood, B BARON others, laughing. A LITERARY ENTHUSIAST approaches, leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your portrait of those men was  terrifying. Terrifying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman and Isherwood watch him walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your hairpiece is terrifying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to say the same thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman laughs loudly. We SEE Nelle look over from across room at her friend having the time of his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman is hung over but immensely gratified. He's with Sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone was there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tennessee loved it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we do more? I was terrified,  but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Now we get to withhold while  everyone else talks. Let them do the  work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman is barely able to suppress his excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This book is going to change  everything. It'll change how people  see you as a writer. It'll change  how people write. You'll finish by  October?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so. You know they're scheduled  for next month?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanging. Yes. I'll commit as many  issues as it takes to publish. Three.  As many as it takes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm flying to Kansas tomorrow. I'll  get Perry to talk --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly, what's he got to lose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman smiles at the joke, then stops himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It really is too awful.  Institutionalized sadism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shawn nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be able to finish now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As strange as it may sound to you,  I'm going to miss him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over black -- the sound of a JET airplane -- loud, then  passing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman, flushed, out of breath, stands outside Perry's ce He's just arrived. He holds a FOLDED-UP NEWSPAPER. Perry  sits at his table reading LEGAL DOCUMENTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry looks up, mistaking Truman's state for shared  enthusiasm. He smiles widely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two days ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard opens the cell for Truman. Perry holds up one o the DOCUMENTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what we've been waiting for. A  stay of execution to make a federal  appeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman enters. Perry goes to him and hugs him tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All thanks to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Truman, shocked, being hugged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman sits on the bed, his coat still on, watching Perry hyped up, talking, walking around the cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kansas's had it in for me for ten  years -- in prison the first time,  at that trial, here. They can't corner  me now. Not till the U.S. Government  says so --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry, sit down. For a minute. (Perry sits) I need you to talk to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got all the time in the world  to talk. About everything. I've been  thinking about Ricardo. You need to  stop sending him those trashy books.  I won't even mention the pornography. (getting up) I realize he might have trouble  grasping the literature you gave me,  but those books only exacerbate the  problem -- only 'heighten' or  'intensify' it. Maybe we should start  him on a program...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him the simple novels first --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what exacerbate means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I thought in case...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is not a word, or a sentence,  or a concept, that you can illuminate  for me. There is one singular reason  that I keep coming here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...November 14th, 1959. Three years  ago. Three years. That's all I want  to hear from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've asked you not to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stands up) This is ridiculous. (to the Guard) I'm ready. (to Perry) I have a plane to catch. I found  your sister in Tacoma. Maybe she'll  talk to me about something useful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard lets Truman out of the cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't go out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my work, Perry. I'm working.  When you want to tell me what I need  to hear, you let me know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off down the hall. The GATE slams shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheaply built ranch house. LINDA MURCHAK (30) walks in th kitchen back door, shuts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll play outside a while longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Murchak looks like a female Perry, dark and small,  attractive and nervous. Through the window, we see THREE  LITTLE CHILDREN playing on a DECREPIT JUNGLE GYM in the y Truman sits at the table, leafing through a PHOTO ALBUM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want them to see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've never seen these pictures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Too many questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She joins Truman again at the table. We see an OLD PHOTO of the SMITH FAMILY -- Linda at age 8 Perry (5); their older sister, June; their brother Frank; and the parents: Florence (American Indian) and John (Iri in front of their rundown truck on a desolate road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: June's dead. Frank shot himself. Now  Perry's did what he did. I suppose  I'm next. Some ruination will visit  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think life works that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does in this family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman turns the page. A PICTURE of Perry (3) and Linda  HOLDING HANDS and splashing in a big mud-puddle in the ra Linda is smiling at Perry, who is naked, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to love him. He was my little  doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the page. A PICTURE of Perry (6) and Linda sitti on the back steps of a shack, poking with a stick at some in the dirt. After a moment, she gets up, clears coffee c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scares me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was the last time you saw him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up the album to put it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I could borrow one of  those pictures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands it to him) Take the whole thing. I don't want'em  anymore. (then) Just... Perry doesn't know where I  live. He thinks we're still in  Portland. Please don't tell him we're  not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he already has) Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be taken in by my brother.  He's got this sensitive side he'll  show. You believe he's gentle, so  easily hurt. But he'd just as soon  kill you as shake your hand. I believe  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman slows for a moment as he passes Hickock's cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello handsome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hickock just stares at him. Truman, unnerved, moves on to Perry's cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry doing pushups. He sees Truman and stops. He stands. The Row Guard approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman regards Perry for a few moments, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard unlocks the door. Perry STARTS TO MOVE toward i The Guard SLAMS it shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the name of your book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response. Perry can barely control his anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the name of your book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the name of your book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry picks up a cut-out ARTICLE from the NY Times from h desk. He reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Truman Capote read last night before  a packed audience from his non-fiction  book IN COLD BLOOD."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More? (reads) "The true-crime novel tells of killers  Richard Hickock and Perry Smith, who  brutally murdered a Kansas family  three years ago."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who sent that to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who sent that to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not your goddamn business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is my business, because it's not  true. The organizers of the reading  needed a title. They picked one -- a  sensational one, I admit -- to attract  a crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They picked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not your title.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't chosen one yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry stares at him, not believing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I choose --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pretend to be my friend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I choose a title when you  still haven't told me what happened  that night? How could I? I couldn't  possibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long pause. Truman reaches in his breast pocket and extra a PHOTO (the one of Perry and Linda splashing in the pudd

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have something from your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands it through the bars to Perry. Perry takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She misses you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry looks at the photo. After a few moments, Truman tur to the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright. I'll go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard unlocks the cell. Truman enters. The Guard lock up, walks away. Perry is still looking at the PHOTO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I should have told you  what they made me call the book. (touches Perry's arm) I couldn't pretend to be your friend.  The truth is, I can't help wanting  to be. (silence, then:) You don't have to tell me anything  if you don't want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry looks at the photo of himself and his sister for a  long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at my belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry sits on the bed. Then, almost to himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be something wrong with  us. To do what we did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman waits him out, sitting on the chair. Finally, Perr looks at him. When Perry speaks, it is quietly, completel matter-of-fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We heard there was ten thousand  dollars in that house. Once we'd  tied up everybody and searched all  over, I knew the guy who told us  about it was wrong. There wasn't any  money. But Dick wouldn't believe it.  He went tearing through the house  again, banging on the walls, looking  for a safe. He said when he was done,  he was going to come up to Nancy's  room and have his way with her. I  wouldn't allow it. I told him that.  I sat with Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry and Nancy. Perry sits quietly on the edge of Nancy' bed. A SMALL BEDSIDE LAMP softly illuminates a portion of the room. We hear Dick banging around downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was nice in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene is almost sweet, until we see that Nancy's legs and hands are TIED and her mouth is TAPED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry talking to Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick came to get me and we turned  out the lights and went down to the  basement, where we had Mr. Clutter  and the boy. Dick kept saying "No  witnesses." I figured if I just waited  him out he'd give up and leave them  tied up there. We'd drive all night,  they'd never find us. Mr. Clutter's  wrists were tied to a pipe over his  head. He looked like he was hurt, so  I cut him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HERBERT CLUTTER is bound and taped, his hands tied to a P on the LOW CEILING. Perry CUTS the rope with a HUNTING KN catches hold of Herb Clutter, lowers him onto a mattress on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry talking to Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We put a box there on the floor so  he'd be more comfortable. He asked  if his wife and daughter were alright  and I said they were fine, they were  ready to go to sleep. I told him it  wasn't long till morning when somebody  would find them. (beat) He was looking at me. Just... looking  at me. Looking at my eyes. Like he  expects me to kill him -- expects me  to be the kind of person who would  kill him. I was thinking -- this  nice man, he's scared of me. I was  ashamed. I mean, I thought he was a  kind man, a good... a gentleman. I  thought so right up to the moment I  cut his throat. I didn't realize  what I'd did till I heard the sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herb Clutter gurgling on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like some one drowning under water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry and Truman. Silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was staring at him, bleeding on  the floor. I told Dick to finish him  off, but he wouldn't do it. We  couldn't leave Mr. Clutter like that,  so I got the shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry approaches with a SHOTGUN. He aims and SHOOTS him i the face.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: KENYON CLUTTER (15) is bound and gagged on an old sofa, a pillow under his head. A flashlight illuminates his face. shotgun enters frame, FIRES. An enormous BURST of LIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bonnie Clutter (40's, small and thin) tied up on her bed. Moonlight through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We went to Mrs. Clutter's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOOR opens. Perry and Dick walk in with a flashlight. Perry points the shotgun at Bonnie's face, FIRES. A BURST LIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry and Dick enter Nancy's room, shine the flashlight o her face. She looks at Perry. She has been crying. After moment, she TURNS HER FACE to the wall, as if she knows w is coming and doesn't want to watch it. Perry AIMS the sh at the back of her head. The FLASHLIGHT switches OFF. The shotgun FIRES. A BURST of LIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry and Truman. Perry still on the bed. Truman sits, no moving, on the chair. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we drove off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Perry looks at Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think of me now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Added up, how much money did you get  from the Clutters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between forty and fifty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman nods. They sit there for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE IN: Hands typing on a MANUAL TYPEWRITER. Truman typing at the desk. He stops, removes the page fro the typewriter, places it on top of a SMALL STACK OF PAGE He sits back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman in his seat, sips a drink. He looks out the window

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman walks with his TRAVEL BAG on his shoulder. He take out his KEYS and turns up the steps to his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. He walks down the hall to the BEDROOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman enters, drops his travel bag on the bed, zips it o removes a SMALL STACK OF TYPED PAGES. He walks to his des On the desk, we see a HUGE STACK OF TYPED PAGES with a ti page on top which reads: IN COLD BLOOD. Truman lifts the  HUGE STACK, places the SMALL STACK under it. He smooths o the pages, then steps back from it. He calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. On Truman, standing in the middle of his room. has finished all that he can finish, and is lost as to wh to do next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE UP:          "One Year Later"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I want to give it to you. The  truth is, I'm desperate to be done  with it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman on the PHONE, in pajamas, looking in the FRIDGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Shawn, I... I've spent four years  of my life on this book... They got  a stay of execution yesterday...  Another, yes....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets out a jar of BONNET BABY FOOD CUSTARD and starts eat it. Truman finds a bottle of J&B on the counter a a shot in his custard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Supreme Court....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stirs the custard, eats it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's harrowing -- all I want is  to write the ending and there's no  fucking end in sight... No. No, I  haven't been drinking again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman sits on the bed with a glass of bourbon, staring a the television. An empty jar of BABY CUSTARD sits on the  bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman on the bed, the television still on, another drink We hear a DOORBELL. We hear Jack walk down the hall, answ the door, shut the door. Jack enters with a TELEGRAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how you can eat that.  Perhaps if you weren't drinking so  much you wouldn't have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response. Jack turns down the television, opens the  telegram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads) "Dear friend Truman. Haven't heard  from you in such a long while. Please  help find new lawyer. If not, Dick  will have to write Supreme Court  brief himself. Our last appeal. What  a pair of wretched creatures. Please  help. Your amigo? Perry."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Jack looks at Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your amigo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman stares back. Finally, he turns back to the televis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it with the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack goes to the DESK and places the telegram on top of a LARGE PILE OF TELEGRAMS, all from Perry -- all, we should assume, unanswered. Jack walks out. Truman sips his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman at the desk, still in PAJAMAS, typing. Jack enters wearing a TUXEDO, reads over Truman's shoulder. We see: "...unable to find laywer despite extensive search. So so All best, Truman."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tried?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman extracts the page from the typewriter, folds it, a puts it in an envelope. He takes a sip of his BOURBON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking out) You need to get ready.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Truman and Jack are driven. Both wear TUXEDOS and OVERCOA Truman drinks.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT, LATER
dialogues.text: Driving. Truman and Jack sit in silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least pretend for Nelle that you're  having a good time tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo turns a corner and we see an ENORMOUS CROWD in f of a THEATER. On the marquee it says: "Opening tonight -

dialogues.speaker: KILL A MOCKINGBIRD"
dialogues.text: It is COLD. Truman and Jack's limo pulls up. An USHER ope their DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman, obviously drunk, preens and poses on the red carp for the CAMERAS. Jack watches from the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge party in progress. Nelle walks through the crowd. Pe turn to her saying: "Congratulations"; "Wonderful". She f Truman sitting at the BAR, receiving a new drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks UNCOMFORTABLY DOLLED UP for the premiere of her movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd find you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Please, another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Nelle his drink, receives another. After a momen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. It's torture. Torture... (he drinks) ...what they're doing to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the Supreme Court. Can you believe  it? If they win this appeal I will  have a complete nervous breakdown. I  may never recover. Just pray things  turn my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's torture. They're torturing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle regards him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how'd you like the movie, Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her drink down on the bar and walks away. Truman turns back to the bartender, shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I frankly don't know what the fuss  is about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Truman, alone at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE UP on a PAPER BOY riding his BIKE down the street. N buds are on the trees. It is SPRING. The BOY wears a NEW  YORK TIMES bag slung over his chest and is tossing copies the paper. One of them lands on Truman and Jack's stoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone RINGING. Truman asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is writing, longhand, at his desk. PHONE is ringing. Jack notices that his door is slightly ajar. He kicks it  shut. The ringing is much quieter. He keeps writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman asleep. PHONE ringing. He wakes up, groggy, answer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Capote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a call from Mr. Perry Smith  in the Kansas Correctional System.  Will you accept charges?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Truman Capote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you accept charges?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (no way out of this) Uh... Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll accept charges?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Smith, you're on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Truman's awake. We hear a series of CLICKS, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman can't bring himself to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? I can't -- (to someone) This doesn't seem -- (we hear Perry clicking  the cradle, then:) Operator, I don't think you put me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They let me make a couple phone calls  before I go down to Holding... You  heard the Supreme Court rejected the  appeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't... I hadn't heard that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. They let me make two phone  calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got a date set for the  Warehouse, Dick and me. Two weeks  and... Finito. April 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you visit me? Truman. Will you  come visit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I can. I'll try. (beat) I don't know if I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear over the line a GUARD in the background:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time, Smith. Hang it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please visit me, Truman. Just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time. Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLICK. Truman sits very still, the phone in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry and Dick being shackled, their belongings packed in boxes. One of the GUARDS in Perry's cell CLANGS the bars  with his STICK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry lies alone on his cot. The DOOR opens, KRUTCH enter with a GUARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry sits up. Krutch sits on the one chair. The Guard st by the door, takes out a PAD and STUBBY PENCIL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're allowed three names of people  you'd like to witness tomorrow. If  there's anybody you want, tell me  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman Capote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krutch nods to the Guard who writes the name down. Krutch waits, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry SHAKES HIS HEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a chair near the window, Truman sits awake in his paja unable to sleep, completely unable to decide what to do. watches Jack sleep. A long time -- then Truman walks to t closet, gets out a travel bag, starts to pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PLANE takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman sits next to William Shawn, who looks exhausted. T STEWARDESS is approaching with the DRINKS CART. She colle an empty BABY CUSTARD JAR from Truman's tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUTSIDE LIGHTS switch on as it gets dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry sits alone. The door opens and a Guard brings in hi LAST MEAL: three hot dogs, french fries, an ice cream sun a strawberry soda. The Guard sets it down on the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (then) You sent the telegram to his hotel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry looks at the CLOCK on the wall: it's after 8pm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I make a phone call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHONE ringing. The CLOCK rads 8:55pm. Empty drinks glasse a custard jar. Truman lies curled in a fetal position on BED. Shawn walks the floor, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman is immobile. Phone still rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've never even met. It is utterly  inappropriate for me to be talking  to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shawn gives up, PICKS UP the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... I'm sorry, he's out, gone  out... I'm not sure when...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krutch walks with a TELEGRAM PAGE in hand. A Guard follow They pass a WALL CLOCK: 9:40pm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krutch and Guard enter Perry's cell. Perry hasn't touched his meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a telex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry nods. Krutch reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Perry. Unable to visit today because  not permitted. Always your friend,  Truman." (apologetically) That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not true, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krutch hesitates a moment, then SHAKES his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelle on the PHONE looking at a TELEGRAM. The kitchen CLO reads 10:20pm. She waits a moment till the line is answer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Shawn? It's Nelle... I just got  this telegram, has he seen it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT with William Shawn on the phone in Truman's hote room. A TELEGRAM lies on the DESK. Truman lies on the bed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't look at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you put him on please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Mr. Shawn, if you have to hold him  down and put the phone on his ear, I  need to speak to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shawn, terrifically uncomfortable, walks over to Truman a holds the phone out to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Nelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment, then Truman takes the phone. On Truman's face. hear, through the receiver, Nelle:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman finally breathes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry is led, SHACKLED, into a holding cell on the ground floor of the Death Row Building. Dick is already there,  seated, shackled. We HEAR PERRY'S VOICE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Miss Nelle Harper Lee and Truman  Capote: Sorry that Truman was unable  to make it here at the prison for a  brief word prior to necktie party...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CLOCK reads 11:05pm. Through the WINDOW, we see activ in the Gallows Warehouse across the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Whatever his reason for not showing  up, I want him to know that I cannot  condemn him for it and understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry makes eye contact with the Guard, who CHEWS GUM. Th Guard checks through the SMALL WINDOW in the door, then  approaches Perry, places a STICK OF GUM in Perry's mouth. Perry CHEWS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Not much time left but want you  both to know that I've been sincerely  grateful for your friendship through  the years and everything else...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman opens the door to the other part of the suite, whe William Shawn is waiting. Truman is fully dressed and rea Perry's VOICE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm not very good at these  things....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TAXICAB pulls up to the prison gates. Perry's VOICE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have become extremely affectionate  toward you both. But, harness time.  Adios amigos. Your friend, Perry."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clock reads 11:35pm. Truman sits with Shawn. Truman is lo at the TELEGRAM from Perry. He folds it, puts it in the b pocket of his jacket. Krutch approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think I'd be seeing you  again. (then) You can visit for a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman stands, turns to Shawn, still seated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman goes alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry, Dick, a Guard. Krutch lets Truman in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits, closes the door. Truman doesn't know what to sa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without rancor) He returns. Long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you must think of  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't been foremost on my mind  lately. As you can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick looks at Perry and smiles. Perry chews his gum and s back, then looks to Truman who seems upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true. I mean I understand why  you didn't want to come. I wouldn't  be here either if I didn't have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got that right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Ricardo donated his eyes to  science? Next week, some blind man  will be seeing what Dick used to  see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) He'd be better off the way he was.  What I've seen hasn't been so nice  to look at -- but I guess it's better  than nothing. (he shrugs, to Truman) They came around with a form. (beat) Hey. You'll be walking down the street  one day in Denver, wherever -- and  suddenly these eyes will be staring  at you. Wouldn't that be something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) It would be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krutch opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman looks at the clock: 11:50pm. Truman turns to Perry and Dick. Perry stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be watching?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Do you want me to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to have a friend there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Then I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman looks down, starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did everything I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I truly did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman nods, wipes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not rid of me yet. I'll see  you in a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman goes. On Perry watching him leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge. Dirt floor. Wooden gallows. TWENTY MEN stand around some smoking. Some are silent. Some whisper quietly. Journalists. Also, Alvin Dewey and the KBI men: Church an Nye. Krutch in front of the gallows with a CHAPLAIN. At t foot of the gallows steps, the EXECUTIONER -- thin, older too-large pin-striped suit and stained cowboy hat. Truman William Shawn. HEADLIGHTS, then a PRISON CAR enters, stops. Dick is extr from the back seat. He stands, looks at the CROWD, then a the GALLOWS. The Guards nudge him forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOCK reads 12:05pm. Perry sits alone looking at his hand We HEAR A TRAP DOOR SPRING and CLATTER. Perry looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light rain outside. Perry in the back seat being driven a the yard. He looks out his window, sees a PICKUP TRUCK dr out of the Corner Warehouse. On it: a BODY covered by a B CLOTH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PRISON CAR enters, stops. Perry is removed from the b seat. He stands, looks at the assembled men, looks at Tru He's nudged forward. As he passes DEWEY, he extends his h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dewey is caught off-guard so shakes his hand. Perry is le to the base of the gallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry Edward Smith. (reads) "For the crime of murder in the first  degree, by order of the Court of  Finney County and the Supreme Court  of the sovereign State of Kansas,  you are sentenced to hang until you  die." (then) You can say something if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, to Krutch) Is there anybody from the family  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry is disappointed by this information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Tell them... (he look out at  everyone) I can't remember what I was going to  say for the life of me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops. Several moments. Krutch can't tell if he's done. Finally, Krutch nods to t Guard. Perry is led up the STEPS. The Chaplain follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though I walk through the valley of  the shadow of death, I will fear no  evil, for thou art with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Executioner puts the NOOSE around Perry's neck. Perry chews his gum. Executioner opens a BLACK CLOTH SACK. Perry looks at the Chaplain reading prayers, looks at the crowd, at Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thy rod and thy staff, they comfort  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BLACK SACK goes over Perry's head. Truman watches. He stands next to Alvin Dewey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thou preparest a table before me in  the presence of mine enemies. Thou  annointest my head with oil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Executioner pulls the handle, Perry drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My cup runneth over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Truman. Then a WIDE SHOT of the inside of the Warehous twenty men watching Perry Smith hang, the Chaplain readin

dialogues.speaker: OVER BLACK
dialogues.text: The SOUND of a TELEPHONE RINGING, as heard through the  receiver. We HEAR the CLICK of the phone being PICKED UP, then, after a moment, a VOICE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman sits on the edge of the bed in his WET OVERCOAT, a if he'd walked in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday I'll tell you about it. For  the moment, I'm too shattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're dead, Truman. You're alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a terrible experience and I  will never get over it. (then) There wasn't anything I could have  done to save them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear Nelle light a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear her exhale slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the fact is, you didn't want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Truman,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman, seated on the aisle, next to William Shawn. After long silence, he extracts from his leather briefcase a PA wrapped in BROWN PAPER. Hands it to Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It came to the hotel this morning. I  told them I'd give it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The package says KANSAS STATE PENITENTIARY and is address to Truman. Truman opens it. He takes out PERRY'S NOTEBOOKS -- the DIARY and PERSONAL  DICTIONARY. He opens the Diary. Toward the end, he finds  Perry's final entry. He READS silently. We hear Perry's V

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did we not know we were to die, we  would be children. By knowing it, we  are given the opportunity to mature  in spirit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman turns the page. It's BLANK. He closes the Diary. We CONTINUE to hear Perry's VOICE as Truman takes out a  SNAPSHOT -- the one of Perry (at age 3) and Linda splashi in the puddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some take that opportunity. I hope I  have...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman takes out a PENCIL DRAWING Perry did of him. It's  very good, though Truman looks old and weary in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is only the father of wisdom.  Death is the mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman finds, at the bottom of the package, his TIE. He t it out, clutches it. Truman grasps for William Shawn's HAND, finds it, holds o tightly. Shawn sits stoically, hoping no one will notice. The CAMERA pulls back, up the aisle. Truman clutches the  tie, and holds on to Shawn's hand, for dear life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE UP: (each title fades up in succession) In Cold Blood made Truman Capote the most famous writer i America. He never finished another book. The epigraph he chose for his last published work reads:  "More tears are shed over answered prayers than unanswere ones. " He died in 1984 of complications due to alcoholism.
